makers.displaydate: 1931–2004; born Cincinnati, OH; died New York, NY; active New York
makers.displaymaker: Tom Wesselmann, 1931–2004; born Cincinnati, OH; died New York, NY; active New York

texts.textentryhtml: Tom Wesselmann, New York, New York, sold; to private collector, consigned; to [Christie's, New York, New York, November 17, 1977, no. 31: Peter Jay Sharp Collection], sold; to  Peter H. Sharp, Caroline M. Sharp, and Randall A. Sharp, Pleasantville, New York; gift to Princeton University Art Museum, 1993.

Like other Pop artists, Wesselmann infused traditional genres—such as portraiture, landscape, still-life, and the nude—with a popular sensibility appropriate to his time. The artist began Great American Nudes, the series for which he is best known, in 1961. These contemporary odalisques mimic those of neoclassical painters like Ingres and modern artists such as Matisse as much as they do mass-produced soft-core erotica. Stripped of both their clothes and their personalities, Wesselmann’s nudes resemble objects more than people. The artist was one of many who abandoned the square or rectangular canvas in favor of the shaped canvas in the 1960s: here, the outlines of the support reiterate the curves of the woman’s body.

Like other Pop artists, Tom Wesselmann infused traditional genres such as portraiture, landscape, still life, and the nude with a popular sensibility. He began his Great American Nudes in 1961. These modern-day odalisques mimic the work of Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres and Henri Matisse as much as they do mass-produced soft-core erotica. Stripped of their clothes as well as their personalities and reduced to a few sexually charged details, his nudes more closely resemble things than people. Wesselmann was one of many artists in the 1960s to abandon the square or rectangle for the shaped canvas: here the outlines of the support reiterate the curves of the woman’s body.
